Graphical abstract Cu-loaded MgAl hydrotalcite catalysts were synthesized by impregnation method and further used for catalytic wet peroxidation (CWPO) of methyl orange (MO) using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant. The synthesized catalysts have been characterized by XRD, FT-IR, SEM/EDS, TG/DTA, XPS, H2-TPR and BET. The characterizations showed that a good dispersion of Cu species inside the MgAl hydrotalcite supports, where Cu2+ and Cu+ species were coexistence, mainly existed as Cu2+ ↔Cu+ pairs. The CuMgAlO catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity due to the high content of Cu2+ ↔Cu+ pairs, stable performance during reuse for five cycles with fewer copper leaching. The degradation mechanism of MO was determined by UV-vis, ATR-FTIR and GC–MS. The hydroxyl radicals (HO) induced strong oxidizing effect, where the azo groups (NN−) double bonds would be first attacked by the hydroxyl radical and other free radicals. With the continuous oxidization, these intermediates could be oxidized to the final oxidation products, such as water and carbon dioxide. Keywords CWPO Degeneration process CuMgAlO catalyst Methyl orange 1 Introduction Different types of dyes are used in many industries such as textile, paint, ink, plastics and cosmetics. A certain amount of them are lost in the process of their manufacturing and utilization and often cause environmental problems. Due to its complex structure, it is very difficult to successfully treat using traditional biological processes [1]. Therefore, the treatment of the effluent containing these compounds is important for the protection of natural waters. Some physicochemical techniques are currently available for the treatment of dye effluent. However, implementation of physical methods such as flocculation, reverse osmosis, and absorption have the inherent drawbacks of being non-destructive, since they merely transfer dye from wastewater effluent, thus causing secondary pollution. Chemical methods such as chlorination and ozonation are also being used for the removal of certain dyes but being economically unfeasible and involving complicated procedures [2]. Thus, Advanced Oxidation Processes (AOPs) including photoelectrocatalysis [3–5], photocatalysis [6], catalytic wet oxidation (CWO) [7] and so forth, which rely on the generation of hydroxyl and other radical species for environmental remediation, have been successfully deployed for the treatment of organic dye wastewater. Although the photocatalytic oxidation can offer good performance for oxidation of refractory organic pollutants, the complexity, high chemical consumption, and relatively high operation costs constitute major barriers for their large-scale applications [8]. In recent years, catalytic wet oxidation (CWO), by adding catalysts and oxidants to improve the oxidation rate, has been found to be very effective in the degradation of dye pollutants, which provide a convenient method for the treatment of undesirable pollutants [7,9]. Among all the possible CWO processes, catalytic wet peroxidation (CWPO) is a well-known process that can be used for the degradation of organic pollutants with the help of a homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant under ambient conditions in low cost installations with low energy consumption [7,9–11]. Homogeneous catalysts are generally very efficient for such reactions, however, these traditional catalytic systems have some technological problems such as difficulties of separation and recovery from the treated effluents. To eliminate these problems, the attention was focused on to develop heterogeneous catalysts [7,12]. Copper as active species is well-known to undergo a Fenton-type reaction and has been used successfully for treating various organic pollutants, which still retains a high efficiency at a higher pH range, and the use of Cu-based catalysts in the CWPO process is incipient [13]. Even though such kinds of Cu-based catalysts such as Cu/13X zeolite, Cu/SBA-15, AlCu-pillared clays and Al-Cu modified clay have been used in CWAO process to degrade the dye wastewater [14–17], little information is available on the degradation mechanism involved in the catalytic degradation of dye. The aim of this work is to evaluate the potential application of a synthesized CuMgAlO catalyst in CWPO using azo dye methyl orange (MO) as a target compound. The physico-chemical properties of the CuMgAlO catalyst were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, SEM/EDS, TG/DTA, XPS, H2-TPR and BET in order to clarify the relationship between structure and catalytic performance. Activity and stability of the CuMgAlO catalyst were investigated in the CWPO of MO, and the degradation mechanism of MO in the CWPO was determined by UV-vis, ATR-FTIR and GC–MS. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All the chemicals used in the study were of analytical reagent grade and solutions were prepared with deionized water. 0.1molL−1 NaOH and HCl solutions were used for pH adjustment. A pH electrode (Mettler Toledo S40K) was used for pH measurements. 2.2 Preparation of the CuMgAlO catalyst The CuMgAlO catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation and impregnation. First, the precursor MgAl hydrotalcite with Mg/Al molar ratio of 4.0 (MgAl-LDH) was prepared by urea hydrolysis according to the literature previously described [18]. Part of the precursor MgAl-LDH was calcined at 500°C for 4h, which was denoted as MgAlO. Second, the CuMgAlO catalyst was prepared by impregnation that 1.00gL−1 of MgAlO was put into 500mL aqueous solution containing 0.01molL−1 CuCl2. The mixture was maintained at 50°C for 12h under stirring (200rpm) before it was filtered. The filter was washed with deionized water to neutrality, and dried at 80°C for 10h, which was denoted as CuMgAl-LDH. Part of the CuMgAl-LDH precursor was calcined at 500°C for 4h and cooled to room temperature, which was denoted as CuMgAlO. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Japan Rigaku D/max 2550PC (λ=1.5405Å) with CuKα radiation. The scan step was 0.02 (2θ) with a filament intensity of 30mA and a voltage of 40kV. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum was recorded on Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One B instrument using KBr pellet technique. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-6700F) and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS, S-4800-I, Hitachi) were used to characterize the surface morphology and the compositions of the samples. The specific surface area, pore volume and diameter were determined by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Hallender (BJH) using a NOVA-e1000 system (Quantachrome, USA), respectively. Before being analyzed, the samples had to be heated at 150°C for 6h to remove surface water. Samples were outgassed at 110°C in vacuum (1×10−4 Torr) for 8h. Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was carried out in a nitrogen atmosphere with a Seiko 6300 TG-DTA instrument with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 under a He stream flowing at 60mLmin−1. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of samples were recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV). The binding energies were calculated with respect to C 1s peak at 285eV with a precision of ±0.2eV. H2-Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was performed out on a Quantachrome ChemBET equipment. For this, 25mg of catalyst (CuMgAlO) was exposed to argon (20mLmin−1) at 200°C for 2h. The sample was cooled to room temperature, and then heated to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 under a 10% H2 in argon stream flowing at 20mLmin−1. The amount of H2 consumption during reduction was monitored by a TCD. 2.4 MO dye degradation 0.3g catalyst (MgAlO, CuO, CuMgAlO and so on) was added into 200mL methyl orange (MO) synthetic wastewater containing 100mgL−1 MO. Then 6mL of 30% H2O2 was added, and the reaction was conducted at 55°C, pH 6.0, magnetic stirrer (150rpm) and atmospheric pressure for 120min. After the reaction, the reaction solution was centrifuged at 7000rpm for 3min. The supernatant was kept for MO measurement by the spectrophotometric method (Hitachi U-2910) at 464nm, and the precipitate was washed three times. The solutions produced from the washing steps were stored for MO determination. PE 5100 PC atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) instrument was used to determine the contents of Cu element in the supernatant. All the experiments were carried out in triplicate under the same condition and average values are reported. The MO degradation rate (η %) was calculated as follows [19], η % = A 0 − A e A 0 × 100 % where A o and A e were the initial and final absorbance values of MO dye, respectively. 2.5 Identification of reaction intermediates During the CWPO, the identification of the intermediates at specified time intervals was performed employing a USA Agillent 6890/5793N gas chromatography-mass spectrometry system (GC–MS). A HP-5 capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm; Hewlett Packard, USA) was used. The column temperature was held at 50°C for 2min and then increased from 50 to 240°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. The MS conditions were EI impact ionization 70eV, helium as the carrier gas, injection temperature 250°C, source temperature 150°C, scanning from m/z 70–350 at 0.3mLmin−1 during the recording mass spectra. When the reactions were completed for 5, 15, 30, 60 and 120min, respectively, the supernatant for each experiment was analyzed by GC–MS. At the same time, the intermediates were also determined using a Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrophotometer and a attenuated total reflectance FT-IR (ATR-FT-IR) instrument, respectively. ATR-FTIR spectra of the sample in the ATR cell was recorded at 2cm−1 resolution and signal averaging of 64 scans on PE Spectrum One B instrument. Background was subtracted using the Opus software. Curve fitting was then performed using Origin 8.0 software and PeakFit v4.12. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the catalysts 3.1.1 XRD analyses To identify the structure change of the catalysts in the preparation, the samples were characterized by XRD and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . the MgAl-LDH precursor displays a typical of MgAl hydrotalcite structure (JCPDS 70-2151) with sharp and intense (003), (006), (009), (110) and (113) reflections. No other crystalline phase is observed, where the interlayer distance (d 003 0.788nm) is typical of CO3 2− hydrotalcite [18,20]. The hydrotalcite-like structure without any reflections of other possible phases is also present in the CuMgAl-LDH, suggesting the complete incorporation of transition Cu species into the crystalline structure. Compared to the MgAl-LDH, the CuMgAl-LDH exhibits broader and less intense reflections with an unstable baseline, indicating a lower crystallinity [21]. This can possibly be explained by the incorporation of Cu species into the MgAl-LDH resulting in a decrease of the hydrotalcite crystallinity [22]. A slight expansion in the interlayer space (d 003 0.802nm) of the CuMgAl-LDH due to the Jahn-Teller effect of the Cu2+ ions [23,24]. The (200) and (220) reflections attributing to the crystallization of periclase-like MgO (JCPDS 75-1525) are observed in the MgAlO sample, which exhibits the typical feature of a mixed oxide of Mg(Al)O due to transforming the hydrotalcite phase into Mg(Al)O phase after calcination [25,26]. Although little CuO phase occurs, no significant positional changes in the basal plane reflections are noted in the CuMgAlO sample, indicating that Cu species are mainly distributed homogeneously in the CuMgAlO oxide matrix [27–29]. 3.1.2 FT-IR analyses Fig. 2 displays the FT-IR spectra of the MgAl-LDH precursor and CuMgAl-LDH in the region 400–4000cm−1, where the FT-IR spectra of the samples were typical of pure hydrotalcite-like structure. The CuMgAl-LDH spectrum is generally similar to the precursor MgAl-LDH one except for some minor differences. Absorption peak at about 3450cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibrations (ν 1−OH) of structural hydroxyl groups in the brucite sheets. The peak at 3450cm−1 is correlated with crystallinity and orderliness, where the narrower half-width at the peak, the higher ordered cation distribution inside the brucite sheets [25,30], suggesting that the CuMgAl-LDH possesses lower crystallinity due to its broader band. And the peak for the CuMgAl-LDH shifts toward lower wavenumber (red-shift 6cm−1), suggesting that the strength of hydrogen bonding decreased. The result is well consistent with that of the XRD analyses (Fig. 1), which also implies a bad long-range ordering (M-OH arrangements, M: Cu, Al, Mg) in the brucite sheets. The peaks at 1380 (ν 3) and 678 (ν 4) cm−1 are resulted from the asymmetrical stretching vibration and the symmetrical stretching vibration of CO3 2−, while the peak at 1630cm−1 is due to the interlayer H2O [18,20]. The peaks around between 500 and 1200cm−1can be attributed to the metal-oxygen vibrations [22]. 3.1.3 SEM/EDS analyses The semi-quantitative analysis of EDS was used to detect the elements of Mg, Al and Cu in the MgAl-LDH and CuMgAl-LDH samples. As seen in Fig. 2, the analyses of EDS reveal that the Mg/Al molar ratios in the MgAl-LDH and CuMgAl-LDH are 3.00 and 1.82, respectively, and the CuMgAl-LDH contains Cu element. The results is confirmed from the XRD and FT-IR analyses. The morphology of the samples is revealed by SEM and shown in Fig. 3 , where thin flat crystals indicate the layered structure for all the samples. The MgAl-LDH and CuMgAl-LDH samples show individually layered platelets, while MgAlO and CuMgAlO samples had some tendency of platelets aggregating into a clumpy manner. Some of the particles can be seen transversely, allowing to estimate the platelet thickness of the MgAl-LDH and CuMgAl-LDH samples. The platelet thickness of the CuMgAl-LDH is obviously thicker than that of the MgAl-LDH. In particular, the surface morphology of the CuMgAl-LDH particles appears the “worm-like” structures formed independently on the edges or defects on the brucite sheets. It is believable that part of the Mg2+ sites were replaced by Cu2+ through isomorphic substitution (Jahn-Teller effect) to form the “worm-like” structures [31,32]. On the other hand, it is evident that particle sizes of the samples, especially CuMgAlO, are definitely decreased after calcination. 3.1.4 Textural properties In order to examine the textural characteristic of the catalysts, BET gas sorptometry measurements were used to characterize pore volume (V P), pore diameter (D P) and specific surface area (S BET). The adsorption isotherms of the metal oxides CuO, MgAlO and CuMgAlO are plotted in Fig. 4 . The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the MgAlO and CuMgAlO belong to typical type IV with a H3 hysteresis loop at high relative pressures, which present a broad poresize distribution in large mesoporous region due to the aggregates of plate-like particles, giving rising to slit-like pores with nonuniform size and almost without macropores [33]. From the nature of the loop, it can be concluded that the pores of MgAlO and its corresponding CuMgAlO are of uniform shape. The BET specific surface area (S BET), total pore volume (V P) and average pore diameter (D P) of the samples determined from these isotherms are summarized in Fig. 4. MgAlO shows the highest surface area (206m2 g−1), while it decreased to 122m2 g−1 when Cu is impregnated, namely CuMgAlO, but the S BET of the CuMgAlO is signifcsntly higher than that (33m2 g−1) of the CuO sample. Although the substitutions of Mg2+ in the brucite sheets by Cu2+ leads to decrease in the specific surface area, the CuMgAlO still matains to possess a large BET surface area (122m2 g−1). It maybe because the CuO nanoparticles (detectable by XRD) and/or Cu-O-Cu clusters finely dispersed on the surface and filled in the mesostructure pores, resulting in the materials with lower surface areas [34]. The textural parameters of MgAlO and CuMgAlO catalysts do not change so greatly, indicating a similarity in the porous structure of the two samples before and after impregnation of Cu. The result presents that MgAlO is a good supports for highly dispersed Cu species. 3.1.5 Thermal analysis Thermal decomposition characteristics of the MgAl-LDH and CuMgAl-LDH are compared in Fig. 5 . The two TG-DTA curves are basically similar and divided in two endothermic peaks, which confirm the strucure of hydrotalcite [35]. The first peak at about around 50–250°C is due to the loss of the surface and interlayer water, and the second peak is at about 252–600°C corresponding to the decomposition of CO3 2− and dehydroxylation in the brucite sheets. The total weight losses at first peak for the MgAl-LDH and CuMgAl-LDH are 17.8 and 17.3%, which at second peak are 21.1 and 22.4%, respectively. The decrease in temperature at both the first and second endothermic peaks reveals the weakening interaction, implying that the removal of water molecules and dehydroxylation become more easy for the CuMgAl-LDH. This may be because Mg is more stabilized in an octahedral coordination of the brucite sheets than Cu, which is inherently less stable in octahedral coordination because of Jahn-Teller effect. These observations are consistent with the results observed by XRD and FT-IR, where the strength of hydrogen bonding in the brucite sheets and between the interlayers decreased due to the presence of Cu species in the brucite sheets. 3.1.6 XPS analysis The chemical states and surface compositions of the CuMgAl-LDH and CuMgAlO were characterized by XPS. Elemental compositions were detected from the areas of O 1s, Al 2p, Cu 2p, Mg 1s and C 1s peaks, confirming the inference from the EDS analysis that the two samples contain Cu, Mg and Al elements. XPS is a surface technique that preferentially detects species located on the surface of a sample (sampling depth is about 3–10nm). In order to obtain more information about the Cu species in the two samples, the core level XPS peaks of Cu 2p for the two samples are shown in Fig. 6 . The Cu 2p spectra show two main peaks that are attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 at about 934.7 and 954.5eV, respectively. The Cu 2p3/2 peak at about 934.7eV, companying with a shake-up peak located at 931.9eV assigning to Cu+ state, belonged to Cu2+ state, meanwhile Cu 2p1/2 peak at about 954.5eV, together with the shakeup satellite structure centered at binding energies of around 943.5 and 962.3eV, also correspond to Cu2+ state [36,37]. It is also clear that Cu2+ and Cu+ species are coexistence, and oxygen vacancies is also in the surface of the two catalysts. Especially, an additional weak peak can be discerned at 952.0eV according with Cu+ state for the CuMgAlO (missing for the CuMgAl-LDH) [38], implying that the amount of Cu+ species is more than that of the CuMgAl-LDH. Especially after calcination, the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 shift to a higher binding energy, also suggesting the increase of Cu+ and the presence of oxygen vacancies, offering the possibility for oxygen storage and release, in the surface of the CuMgAlO [39]. It has been reported that Cu+ is the active intermediate for the hydroxylation of phenol using H2O2 [40]. So, it is also clear that Cu2+ and Cu+ species (Cu2+ ↔Cu+) are coexistence in the CuMgAlO and CuMgAl-LDH catalysts, and more Cu+ enhanced the catalytic activity of the CuMgAlO in the CWPO of MO. The results indicate that calcination facilitates the formation of Cu+ species, and the CuMgAlO had higher catalytic activity than the CuMgAl-LDH due to more amount of Cu2+ and Cu+ species (Cu2+ ↔Cu+ pairs). The higher catalytic activity of the CuMgAlO can be testified by subsequent catalysis experiments. 3.1.7 H2 −TPR analysis The fact that copper species are hardly detected in the CuMgAlO sample indicates that the species are either highly dispersed as small CuO crystallites detectable by XRD or forming a solid solution within the oxide lattice that can exist in Cu2+↔Cu+ pairs form on the surface of the CuMgAlO oxide matrix (XPS). To get insight into this issue, the reducibility of Cu species in the CuMgAlO sample calcined at 500°C was investigated by H2-TPR. Fig. 7 shows the reduction profiles of the CuMgAlO sample. For comparison, the H2-TPR profile of pure CuO is also collected in Fig. 7, which shows a single peak with maximum at 238°C. For the MgAlO, no reduction peak is detected until 800°C. The profile of the CuMgAlO sample shows one intense peak with a maximum at 300°C and a shoulder at 146°C in the same temperature range as that of pure CuO. The intense peak is assigned to the reduction of Cu2+ ions (Cu2+ to Cu+) incorporated in Mg(Al)O phase, while the shoulder peak is assignable to the reduction of CuO [41]. With the replacement of Cu for Mg, the reduction peak shifted toward higher temperature comparing with that of CuO, which means that the interaction between the copper species and the Mg(Al)O is enhanced [42]. This result confirms the hypothesis from the analysis result by XRD, TG-DTA and BET that Cu species are mainly distributed homogeneously in the CuMgAlO oxide matrix, which results in difficult reduction of Cu2+ and higher reduction temperatures. This result matches with that obtained with the XRD analysis, where peaks associated to CuO phase is the slender peaks observed in the CuMgAlO sample. At the same time, the CuMgAlO had more Cu2+ and Cu+ species (Cu2+ ↔Cu+) and oxygen vacancies by the aid of the XPS analyses, comparing with its precusor CuMgAl-LDH. 3.2 Catalytic performances of the catalysts 3.2.1 Catalytic activity of the catalysts In the work reported here, the activity of the catalysts was investigated to determine its suitability for the degradation of azo dye methyl orange (MO) in the CWPO. Fig. 8 summarizes the color removal efficiencies of MO using CuO, MgAl-LDH, MgAlO, CuMgAl-LDH and CuMgAlO as catalysts, respectively. The CuMgAlO shows promising catalytic activity (close to 100%) at 55°C with high mineralization efficiency at atmospheric pressure. The catalytic activity of the five samples is in the following sequence: CuMgAlO>CuO>MgAlO≥CuMgAl-LDH>MgAl-LDH. When the reaction was performed in the presence of the CuMgAl-LDH and MgAl-LDH, the degradation rates are only 20.8 and 36.7%, respectively. By using the mixed oxides (CuMgAlO and MgAlO) as catalysts, they are elevated to 99.2% and 41.5%, respectively, indicating that the mixed oxides are more effective catalysts compared to their correspending precursors. Higher catalytic performance of the CuMgAlO catalyst confirms the inference from XPS analyses that the CuMgAlO has more Cu2+ ↔Cu+ site pairs on the surface of the CuMgAlO matrix. And the homogeneous interdispersion of Cu species and high specific surface areas also make the CuMgAlO highly catalytic activity, which is in good agreement with the previous results [18,26,35,43,44]. It can be concluded that the removal efficiency can be greatly improved through introducing Cu spices into the MgAlO catalyst. The promoted catalytic activity can be attributed to the special ability of Cu: (1) better dispersion of Cu spices achieved when CuMgAlO calcined at 500°C increases the number of effectively active sites, and the increase helps the instant production of more HO· and HO2·, where the MgAlO can act as a good support for CuMgAlO catalyst; (2) the introduction of Cu, especially Cu2+ ↔Cu+ site pairs on the surface of the CuMgAlO matrix, increases the content of chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface, thereby improving the redox properties, and so, Cu can act as an electronic promoter of the CuMgAlO catalyst. With reference to above characterization results and catalytic activities of the catalysts, the CuMgAlO is used as the catalyst for further experiments. 3.2.2 Stability of the CuMgAlO catalyst The recycling and reuse of catalysts have often been problematic because of the instability and/or leaching. For practical applications, the stability and reusability of the CuMgAlO catalyst were very important factors. To clarify this issue, the experiment was established using the recycled CuMgAlO catalyst. We performed five runs using of the catalyst after filtration, washing for removing the reaction solution attaching the catalyst, and then calcined again at 500°C. The CuMgAlO catalyst was reused for the next run under the same conditions, and the results in the five recycle experiments were shown in Fig. 9 . The slightly leaching of active Cu species was also detected, giving the Cu concentration of 4.2mgL−1 in the first cycle, and Cu were not detected except of first cycle (Fig. 9). At the same time, at the second cycle, the catalytic activity of the CuMgAlO (89.3%) declined mainly due to Cu species leaching. In the subsequent cycles, the catalyst became deactivated after each run, but the catalyst could be recycled without obvious loss in activity and kept over 83.1% in the five recycles. The results show that the CuMgAlO catalyst has high reusability and stability, which could be attributed to the stable structure of the CuMgAlO catalyst. 3.2.3 Degeneration process of azo dye MO 3.2.3.1 UV–vis analyses UV-vis absorption measurement is a very simple method and applicable to the binding study of small molecule substances, which is used as a sensitive measure of subtle changes in molecule structure. The change of the UV–vis spectra of the reaction intermediates at different reaction times are shown in Fig. 10 . The UV–vis absorption is characterized by one peak in the visible region with maxima located at 460nm and by one peak in the ultraviolet region located at 270nm, which are referred to azo linkage and benzene ring, respectively [45]. The intensity of the peak in visible region declined as the treatment time increased, and almost totally disappeared after 120min of catalytic degradation, demonstrating that the azo linkage of most methyl oranges can be destroyed in 120min. At the same time, the intensity of the peak at 270nm increases in the first 5min and then decreases until to the baseline of the spectra after 120min. The results indicate that the HO radicals attacked the azo bonds in MO initially and caused the cleavage of the azo groups (NN) double bonds. In order to obtain more information on MO degradation, ATR-FTIR was employed. 3.2.3.2 ATR-FTIR analyses To review the degradation behavior and molecular breaking of azo dye MO in the CWPO, the ATR-FTIR spectra of the intermediates for different time lengths are shown in Fig. 11 . The peaks at 1033, 1124 and 1189cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric stretching vibration in the −SO3Na group as well as the coupling between the benzene mode and νsSO3 [46]. The intensity of the peak at 1033cm−1 reduces over degradation time, and eventually vanishes for 30min, demonstrating that the desulfuration occurred. The new peak is found at 1157cm−1 and it corresponds to CO groups of alcohols, while another new peak at 1340cm−1 corresponded to OH appears [45,46]. The new peak is also observed at 1256cm−1, with the vibration stretching modes ν(CN) and ν(NN), respectively. The appearance of the three new peaks means that the aromatic derivatives are very susceptible to oxidation, and as a result, aliphatic and inorganic intermediates are produced. The characteristic peak observed in 1370 and 1420cm−1 is due to the NN bond and to the aromatic ring vibrations sensitive to the interaction with the azo bond, or to the bending vibration mode δ (NN) of the hydrazone form of the azo dye [45,46], which disappears after 5min reaction due to the brokening of the azo bond. And the peaks at 1520, 1598 and 1669cm−1 are linked to benzene rings and weaken with reaction time lasting until they disappear after 15min as the cleavage of the benzene ring. The results show that the HO· radicals caused the cleavage of NN double bonds which is easier to be destroyed than aromatic compounds because the electron rich azo bond is the most active site in the dye molecule, which match the results from the UV–vis analyses. Meanwhile, the new peak at 1645cm−1 attributed to the stretching vibration of CO groups of carboxylic acids is generated after 30min, where there is a significant increase in the intensity over degradation time, and then decreases for 120min. The changes of the new peak may be due to different structures of carboxylic acids from different reaction times. These results demonstrate the degradation process of MO molecule and the formation of intermediates in CWPO using the CuMgAlO as catalyst. The degradation intermediates were further analyzed by using GC/MS. 3.2.3.3 GC–MS analyses The GC–MS analysis was performed for MO degradation, and the formation of intermediates during the degradation process was identified by this technique. As radicals play a significant role in the degradation of MO, the reaction between Cu2+/Cu+ takes place in the presence of H2O2 forming reactive hydroxyl (HO) and hydroperoxyl (HOO) radicals (Scheme 1 ), which can be described as follows, Cu 2 + + H 2 O 2 ↔ CuOOH + + H + CuOOH + → Cu + + H + + O 2 − Cu + +H 2 O 2 → Cu 2 + + ⋅ OH + OH − H 2 O 2 + ⋅ OH → -H 2 O HOO ⋅ → +OH − O 1 2 +H 2 O MO + ⋅ OH → MO ( HO ⋅ ) → Intermediate + ⋅ OH → CO 2 +H 2 O The sample before the MO degradation shows two m/z peaks at 304 of high intensity attributed to ionization of the dye MO molecule. The sample after 5min of degradation shows two m/z peaks of high intensity at 173 and 136 and two lower intensities m/z peak at 151 and 121, which corresponds to 4-aminosulfonic acid, N,N-dimethyl-p-phenylenediamine, 4-Hydrazinyl-N,N-dimethylbenzenamine and N,N-dimethyl- phenylamine, respectively. This shows that degradation proceeds through the cleavage of azo group NN connecting two aromatic rings to amines as shown in Scheme 2 , which agree with the results in the literature [47–49]. The sample after 15min shows three m/z peaks at 111, 110 and 94 of high intensity, which corresponds to 3,5-diallyl amide, 1,4-paradioxybenzene and phenol, respectively. The sample after 30min shows m/z peaks at 108, 71 and 56 may be due to the formation of 2,5-cyclohexadiene-1,4-dione (or 3,5-cyclohexadiene-1,2-dione), acrylamide and acrolein. After 60min, the intermediates again get converted into short chain organic acids such as maleic acid (m/z 116), oxalic acid (m/z 90), crylic acid (m/z 72), acetic acid (m/z 60) and formic acid (m/z 46) with progress of time. Finally organic acids get destructed into CO2 and H2O for 120min, which is consistent with the previous studies [50]. Based on the intermediates analyzed by GC–MS, ATR-FTIR and UV–vis techniques, a probable degradation mechanism is proposed in Scheme 2. 4 Conclusions The CuMgAlO was obtained from MgAl-LDH precursor where Cu species were introduced in the brucite-like layers, which showed a potential catalytic activity in the CWPO of MO by hydrogen peroxide as oxidant. Cu species incorporation into the framework of the MgAlO support was confirmed by various characterization (XRD, FT-IR, SEM/EDS, TG/DTA, XPS, H2-TPR and BET) studies, where Cu2+ and Cu+ species were coexistence in the CuMgAlO. Results showed that the CuMgAlO catalyst exhibited best catalytic activity with 99.2% MO degradation rate, which had good operational stability during recycling test with high catalytic activity and low copper leaching. Combining with the UV–vis and ATR-FTIR techniques, the GC–MS analysis showed that the degradation process could be that the aromatic group connecting with azo double bond was oxidized to benzene derivatives by hydroxyl radicals, where the benzene rings were further destroyed after 15min, and generated new smaller molecular such as acetic acid and oxalic acid etc. Acknowledgment This work is supported by the Key Project of Hunan Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (12JJ2008). coredata.dc:description: Cu-loaded MgAl hydrotalcite catalysts were synthesized by impregnation method and further used for catalytic wet peroxidation (CWPO) of methyl orange (MO) using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant. The synthesized catalysts have been characterized by XRD, FT-IR, SEM/EDS, TG/DTA, XPS, H2-TPR and BET. The characterizations showed that a good dispersion of Cu species inside the MgAl hydrotalcite supports, where Cu2+ and Cu+ species were coexistence, mainly existed as Cu2+ ↔Cu+ pairs. The CuMgAlO catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity due to the high content of Cu2+ ↔Cu+ pairs, stable performance during reuse for five cycles with fewer copper leaching. The degradation mechanism of MO was determined by UV-vis, ATR-FTIR and GC–MS. The hydroxyl radicals (HO) induced strong oxidizing effect, where the azo groups (NN−) double bonds would be first attacked by the hydroxyl radical and other free radicals. With the continuous oxidization, these intermediates could be oxidized to the final oxidation products, such as water and carbon dioxide.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic properties of CuMgAlO catalyst and degradation mechanism in CWPO of methyl orange
